case_vignette: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her mother who is concerned about a new rash. Her daughter is otherwise feeling well, is up to date on vaccinations, and has not traveled recently. The family lives in an old apartment building. She is currently excelling in school and has many friends. Physical exam is notable for the finding in Figure A.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a new rash.
How old are you?
I'm 9 years old.
Are you experiencing any other symptoms besides the rash?
No, I'm otherwise feeling well.
Where is the rash located on your body?
I can't tell where the rash is, my mom noticed it.
Can your mom describe the rash and exactly where it is on your body?
Sorry, but my mom isn't the one being asked right now, so I can't answer that.
Understood. Have you recently had any new foods, medications, or come into contact with any new plants or animals?
No, I haven't had any new foods, medications, or contact with new plants or animals.
Is the rash itchy or painful?
The rash isn't itchy or painful.
Do you have a fever or have you recently been ill?
No, I haven't had a fever or been ill recently.
Does the rash appear to be spreading or changing over time?
I don't know, my mom just noticed the rash.
Have you noticed any changes in the texture or color of your skin where the rash is, such as raised bumps or redness?
The physical exam found something about the rash, but I can't describe any changes in texture or color myself.
Do you have any known allergies?
No, I don't have any known allergies.
Has anyone in your family had a similar rash or any known skin conditions?
Not that I know of, no one in my family has had a similar rash or skin conditions.

Without more specific information on the characteristics of the rash or the ability to observe its progression, a definitive diagnosis cannot be reached at this moment. I recommend a follow-up with a physical exam to obtain more details about the rash.
